subject: RE: [junit] How can I get Junit Test to run in parallel threads?
msgSnippet: ... Dave: An excellent question indeed! The answer is that we are following the model that many companies such as Sun (NetBeans- Forte), Red Hat, Suse etc.
messageBody:
Dave Astels wrote:
> On Wed, 2002-10-02 at 16:25, Michael Silverstein wrote:
>
> We have a product called 'Enhanced JUnit' (hence my interest in JUnit
> extensibility issues) that (among other things) will disburse
> JUnit tests
> across threads, VMs, and CPUs for concurrent execution.
>
> http://www.silvermark.com/Product/enhancedjunit/
>
> Not to start a flame war... but why don't you follow Beck&Gamma's
> example and give it to the JUnit community as so many others have done
> with their extensions?
>
> Dave

Dave:

An excellent question indeed!

The answer is that we are following the model that many companies such as
Sun (NetBeans->Forte), Red Hat, Suse etc. (Linux->branded Linux), Rational
(Eclipse->XDE), IBM (Eclipse->WSAD) pioneered, where they build commercial
tools that add to open source tools.

Don't forget that many commercial IDE vendors reship JUnit in an effort to
add value to their own products. Likewise, there are people who earn their
living writing books and consulting around open source tools, or use open
source tools in one way or another to promote their own ventures. For
example, "The Coad Letter: Test-driven Development Edition, issue 102:
JUnit" written by yourself asks that the reader "consider Saorsa's intensive
5-day, Hands-on TDD course taught by Dave Astels." I assume you are not
giving this course away for free.

In the case of Enhanced JUnit, it is a little strange because we are
actually grafting some functionality that already exists in an enterprise
testing tool (Test Mentor) onto JUnit. There is actually more code (and
functionality) in the add-on than JUnit.

I hope this helps, Mike
